title: Bartz v. Anthropic
headline: Bartz v. Anthropic - rules AI training fair use.
summary:
Summaries: Bartz v. Anthropic — Anthropic chooses to pay the largest known copyright settlement in history — but so far, the Court won’t let them! A few weeks ago, we saw that the Bartz plaintiffs (book authors and rights-holders) and Anthropic had reached a proposed settlement of $1.5 Billion. There are roughly 500,000 copyrighted works subject to the settlement, resulting is about $3,000 per work. Although this is certainly an historic and watershed moment in AI training litigation, we need to put it in context. But last week, Judge Alsup refused to approve the settlement. The Judge instead demanded more information about the settlement. So will it happen? Won’t it? Stay tuned for more. But recall that Judge Alsup’s summary judgment ruling didn’t fault Anthropic for training its AI on copyrighted works. Rather, Alsup found that pirating copyrighted works to create a general-purpose digital library for Anthropic to use however it wanted was not “fair use.” In another case decided that same week several weeks ago, Judge Vince Chhabria (in the same federal district) ruled that Meta’s acquisition of copyrighted materials through torrenting was not copyright infringement because the purpose of the acquisition was to train an AI system, which both Chhabria and Alsup found to be fair use. According to Alsup, Anthropic’s violation here is not training its AI, but taking hundreds of thousands of copyrighted works for whatever purpose it wanted. Arguably, if Anthropic had simply purchased the copyrighted works (likely for far less than $3,000 a copy) it would have been clear to train its AI however it chose — although, to be clear, Judge Chhabria would likely reach a different result.

Key takeaway: Fair-use outcomes may hinge on record-specific market-harm proof.
music_lens: Settlement magnitude (~$3k/work) is a valuation anchor. Push provenance audits and disclosure of acquisition sources; leverage Bartz’s acquisition-vs-training split to frame composition claims and negotiations.

title: Disney & Universal v. Midjourney
headline: Disney & Universal v. Midjourney
summary: Summaries: Disney & Universal v. Midjourney — No major substantive developments this past week . There has been little substantive development in this case since the filing of the answer. If it has not already happened, the parties will need to have their initial Rule 26(f) discovery conference to get the litigation rolling. Discovery will then begin in earnest and we will hopefully get some trickles of what the parties find out.
music_lens: Visual-art rulings on inducement and output similarity can carry over: document AI outputs that recreate lyric structure/phrases to support composition claims and push for output filtering obligations.

title: Disney v. Minimax and Hailuo AI - NEW CASE ALERT
headline: Disney v. Minimax and Hailuo AI - NEW CASE ALERT
summary: Summaries: Disney v. Minimax and Hailuo AI - NEW CASE ALERT — Newly filed . Disney, Universal Studios, and Warner Brothers filed suit against AI companies offering video generation products. Like their previous complaints against Midjourney, Disney’s complaint shows numerous examples in which users of these products have generated videos — including Plaintiffs’ copyrighted characters. The complaint alleges two causes of action: direct and secondary copyright infringement. Although the complaint is similar to ones that we have seen before, this is one of the first cases involving video content rather than simply text or images. We will continue to provide updates as this case develops.
music_lens: Build evidentiary files on lyric/composition market harm (lost sync, sheet music, lyric licensing) and compel disclosure of training datasets and ingestion logs.

title: Getty Images v. Midjourney and Stability AI
headline: Getty Images v. Midjourney and Stability AI
summary: Summaries: Getty Images v. Midjourney and Stability AI — Still no update for Getty . With no notable updates for Getty in over a third of a year, this case on the back-burner. As a final update on where we last left off: Getty had submitted a letter to the Court on November 25th, 2024 explaining its frustration with Stability AI’s refusal to participate in discovery or participate in a Rule 26(f) conference. In August 2024, Stability AI had argued that they were under no obligation to commence fact discovery until the Court issued its ruling on jurisdiction. Getty had requested that the Court order Stability to stop delaying and proceed with the case, but after several months with no response from the Court, it appears unclear when things will begin moving forward again.
music_lens: Visual-art rulings on inducement and output similarity can carry over: document AI outputs that recreate lyric structure/phrases to support composition claims and push for output filtering obligations.

title: Hendrix v. Apple
headline: Hendrix v. Apple - motion to dismiss briefing.
summary: Summaries: Hendrix v. Apple — No major substantive developments this past week . Two weeks ago a group of authors filed a putative class-action lawsuit against Apple for work that Apple has done training its family of OpenELM models, which are hosted on HuggingFace and which Apple has discussed in published papers. The Plaintiffs in this class allege similar theories to those in prior cases, including that Apple illegally “torrented” books from the books3 database to train its AI platform. Plaintiffs’ complaint alleges only one cause of action: direct copyright infringement under 17 U.S.C. § 501. As we’ve seen with other cases, the next step is for Apple to file an answer, motion to dismiss or other responsive pleading. The standard deadline for a responsive pleading is 21 days, but extensions are common, particularly in complex litigation like this. Check back in the coming weeks as this new matter develops.
music_lens: Build evidentiary files on lyric/composition market harm (lost sync, sheet music, lyric licensing) and compel disclosure of training datasets and ingestion logs.

title: Kadrey v. Meta
headline: Kadrey v. Meta
summary: Summaries: Kadrey v. Meta — No major substantive developments this past week . The Kadrey matter has been quiet for the past months. Last week was not much different, but we did see a dispute over a recently clawed-back document produced by Meta. According to Plaintiffs, Meta produced a document and then attempted to claw back one line as privileged. Despite pages of briefing by Meta (and one paragraph by Plaintiffs), Judge Chhabria ordered the document produced for in camera review the following day.
music_lens: Fair-use win here hinged on record-specific market-harm showings. For compositions, build a damages narrative tied to substitution (lyrics, sheet music, sync) and document lost licensing opportunities to survive early motions.

title: Plaintiffs v. Anthropic
headline: Plaintiffs v. Anthropic
summary: Summaries: Plaintiffs v. Anthropic — Plaintiffs request more time for fact discovery. Last week the Court rejected Anthropic’s demands that Plaintiffs supplement their disclosures to explain how they intend to calculate damages in this case. The Court indicated that Plaintiffs had complied with their obligations at this stage per relevant Rule 26 and noted that fact discovery did not close for another month. Not long after this ruling, however, Plaintiffs submitted a motion requesting that the close of fact discovery be extended for two months following the resolution of pending discovery motions. The Court has not yet decided the motion, so check back next week to find out how long it will be before Plaintiffs begin explaining their theories in detail.
music_lens: Build evidentiary files on lyric/composition market harm (lost sync, sheet music, lyric licensing) and compel disclosure of training datasets and ingestion logs.

title: Plaintiffs v. Perplexity AI
headline: Plaintiffs v. Perplexity AI - motion to dismiss briefing.
summary: Summaries: Plaintiffs v. Perplexity AI — Going into deep freeze. It has been several months since Plaintiffs submitted their memorandum of law opposing Defendant’s motion to dismiss or transfer the case. We’re going to put this case on the back burner until there is some substantial movement on the docket.
music_lens: RAG systems pose ongoing reproduction risks. Assert claims on output reproduction of lyrics and require link-respecting behavior; consider negotiating paid access APIs for lyric metadata as an alternative.

title: Reddit v. Anthropic
headline: Reddit v. Anthropic
summary: Summaries: Reddit v. Anthropic — Anthropic opposes remand . As we discussed in last week’s update, this case has been removed to the Northern District of California after it was originally filed in California state court. Reddit has requested that the case be remanded to state court, which Anthropic unsurprisingly opposes. Last week, Anthropic filed its opposition to Reddit’s motion to remand. Anthropic is arguing that Reddit’s state law claims for breach of contract, unjust enrichment, tortious interference, and unfair competition were preempted and, thus, the Court should exercise jurisdiction over the remaining claims.
music_lens: TOS/robots-based claims highlight enforceable access controls. Harden publisher lyric-site terms and robots.txt, and preserve access logs to support contract/DMCA 1201 theories against unlicensed scrapers.

title: Sarah Andersen v. Stability AI
headline: Sarah Andersen v. Stability AI - dismisses AI/IP claims.
summary: Summaries: Sarah Andersen v. Stability AI — No major substantive developments this past week . Several weeks ago, the parties’ extended dispute over whether Dr. Ben Zhao should be allowed to see confidential material in order to act as Plaintiffs’ expert was put to rest when the Court denied Plaintiffs’ motion to overturn the “very thorough” order by Magistrate Judge Cisneros which also denied Dr. Zhao permission to view such materials. Subsequently, the Court held a discovery status conference in the case, though no substantive docket entries resulted.
music_lens: Visual-art rulings on inducement and output similarity can carry over: document AI outputs that recreate lyric structure/phrases to support composition claims and push for output filtering obligations.

title: SDNY Multi-District Litigation
headline: SDNY Multi-District Litigation
summary:
Summaries: SDNY Multi-District Litigation — No major substantive developments this past week . Following what may have been the busiest week since the multi-district litigation commenced, last week saw only a few docket entries, none of which were discovery disputes. Instead, the Court only ordered a confidential settlement conference to discuss the ongoing dispute regarding output logs on September 26th. OpenAI and the News Plaintiffs had previously briefed disputes over OpenAI’s deletion of ChatGPT output logs which Plaintiffs argued contained evidence relevant to their infringement claims.

Key takeaway: Settlement figures are emerging benchmarks for per-work valuation.
music_lens: Coordinate with aligned plaintiffs; file amicus on market-harm factors relevant to compositions. Track scheduling to time publisher filings with key expert discovery milestones.

title: The New York Times v. Microsoft & OpenAI
headline: The New York Times v. Microsoft & OpenAI
summary: Summaries: The New York Times v. Microsoft & OpenAI — OpenAI objects to preservation order. As we discussed previously, the Court has maintained its order for OpenAI to preserve chat logs that would otherwise be deleted under its privacy policies, citing concerns that the same users who might use ChatGPT to circumvent The New York Times ’ paywall protections would be more likely to request deletion of their chat logs. OpenAI has maintained its objections to this order. In its Objection to Preservation Order, OpenAI raised three main arguments. First, that the preservation order does not serve a useful purpose because the idea that certain users attempt to “cover their tracks” is far-fetched. Second, they argued that the Order is not proportional to the needs of the case, because it would require OpenAI to make infrastructural changes to support the retention and would strain user trust in OpenAI. Finally, OpenAI argued that the preservation order was based on false premises, stating that OpenAI did not “destroy” any data, and certainly did not delete any data in response to litigation events. OpenAI’s false-premises argument cites support from a non-public declaration, but it appears that OpenAI may be relying on a narrow distinction between “deleting” data (which it is arguing is needed to maintain customer trust) and “destroying” data which the News Plaintiffs could argue gives rise to adverse inference.
music_lens: Preservation obligations may unlock ingestion and output logs. Request parallel preservation and model-audit protocols in music cases to surface lyric/composition usage and quantify market harm.

title: Thomson Reuters v. Ross Intelligence
headline: Thomson Reuters v. Ross Intelligence - rules AI training fair use.
summary:
Summaries: Thomson Reuters v. Ross Intelligence — We are still awaiting the “fair use” determination by the Third Circuit Court of Appeals, after the federal district court had certified Ross’ fair-use and copyrightability arguments for interlocutory appeal. On April 4th, the federal district court judge granted Ross Intelligence’ motion for interlocutory appeal off the Court’s summary judgment ruling against Ross’ “fair use” and copyrightability arguments. The Court stated that “Though I remain confident in my February 2025 summary judgment opinion, I recognize that there are substantial ground for difference of opinion on controlling legal issues in this case.” The two questions certified are “ (1) whether the West headnotes and West Key Number System are original; and (2) whether Ross’s use of the headnotes was fair use.” We’re not particularly surprised at this development. The country is watching this case rather closely because of its proximity to the generative AI training cases, and the hundreds of billions of dollars at stake there. Trying the case without considering the certified questions, and then having those issues reversed on appeal could waste everyone’s resources.

Key takeaway: Fair-use outcomes may hinge on record-specific market-harm proof.
music_lens: Court’s emphasis on market impact is instructive: develop evidence that unlicensed training forecloses licensing for compositions/lyrics. Frame publisher markets distinctly from any proposed 'training-license' market.

title: UMG Recordings v. Suno
headline: UMG Recordings v. Suno
summary: Summaries: UMG Recordings v. Suno — UMG Recordings requests leave to amend their complaint . Last week, Plaintiff UMG Recordings submitted a motion for leave to amend their complaint to include an additional claim regarding circumvention of technological measures. According to the proposed amendment, Suno engaged in unauthorized “stream ripping” audio content from YouTube in order to build a training set for its models. In its memorandum of law, UMG Recordings argued that it had been diligent in discovering this circumvention and therefore that it should be permitted to add this third claim to its case.
music_lens: Label-led pleadings focus on sound recordings; monitor discovery for training-data disclosures. If lyrics or compositions appear in ingestion logs, be prepared to assert composition-specific claims and request preservation of training artifacts.

title: UMG Recordings v. Uncharted Labs
headline: UMG Recordings v. Uncharted Labs
summary: Summaries: UMG Recordings v. Uncharted Labs — No major substantive developments this past week . The docket in his case has seen very little development in the past months. However, the parties have agreed to an extension of time for document production, pushing the completion date out to October 10th.
music_lens: Label-led pleadings focus on sound recordings; monitor discovery for training-data disclosures. If lyrics or compositions appear in ingestion logs, be prepared to assert composition-specific claims and request preservation of training artifacts.

title: Warner Bros. Discovery v. Midjourney
headline: Warner Bros. Discovery v. Midjourney
summary: Summaries: Warner Bros. Discovery v. Midjourney — Warner Bros. Discovery joins the fight against Midjourney! On September 4th, Warner Bros. Discovery sued Midjourney in the United States District Court for the Central District of California alleging direct and secondary copyright infringement. The complaint is similar in many ways to Disney and Universal’s showing dozens of strikingly similar images where Midjourney’s outputs mimic Warner Bros. copyrighted characters. The fact that Warner Bros. also picked Midjourney as a sole target speaks volumes about Midjourney’s uniquely dismissive attitude towards copyright and generative AI. The next step will be for Midjourney to file an answer or other responsive pleading. We expect an answer from Midjourney will track the answer in the case against Disney and Universal, claiming fair use and that it does not control what its users create. Three of the “Big Five” studios have now sued Midjourney, leaving only Sony and Paramount on the sidelines. We will see if they follow suit.
music_lens: Outputs mimicking protected characters strengthen arguments that AI can reproduce protected expression. For lyrics/compositions, pursue evidence that prompts yield lyric-like outputs and prepare injunctive relief asks tied to output filters.
